t: Proverbs 24
Saying 20
Do*pn not envy the wicked, do*ld not desire their company;
for*ln their hearts plot violence, and*ld their lips talk about making trouble.
Saying 21
By*pn wisdom a house is built, and*ld through understanding it is established;
through*ln knowledge its rooms are filled with*ld rare and beautiful treasures.
Saying 22
The*pn wise prevail through great power, and*ld those who have knowledge muster their strength.
Surely*ln you need guidance to wage war, and*ld victory is won through many advisers.
Saying 23
Wisdom*pn is too high for fools; in*ld the assembly at the gate they must not open their mouths.
Saying 24
Whoever*pn plots evil will*ld be known as a schemer.
The*ln schemes of folly are sin, and*ld people detest a mocker.
Saying 25
If*pn you falter in a time of trouble, how*ld small is your strength!
Rescue*ln those being led away to death; hold*ld back those staggering toward slaughter.

If*ln you say, “But we knew nothing about this,” does*ld not he who weighs the heart perceive it? Does*ln not he who guards your life know it? Will*ld he not repay everyone according to what they have done?
Saying 26
Eat*pn honey, my son, for it is good; honey*ld from the comb is sweet to your taste.
Know*ln also that wisdom is like honey for you: If*ld you find it, there is a future hope for you, and*ld your hope will not be cut off.
Saying 27
Do*pn not lurk like a thief near the house of the righteous, do*ld not plunder their dwelling place;
for*ln though the righteous fall seven times, they rise again, but*ld the wicked stumble when calamity strikes.
Saying 28
Do*pn not gloat when your enemy falls; when*ld they stumble, do not let your heart rejoice,
or*ln the Lord*s will see and disapprove and*ld turn his wrath away from them.
Saying 29
Do*pn not fret because of evildoers or*ld be envious of the wicked,
for*ln the evildoer has no future hope, and*ld the lamp of the wicked will be snuffed out.
Saying 30
Fear*pn the Lord*s and the king, my son, and*ld do not join with rebellious officials,
for*ln those two will send sudden destruction on them, and*ld who knows what calamities they can bring?
Further Sayings of the Wise
These*p also are sayings of the wise: To*pn show partiality in judging is not good:
Whoever*ln says to the guilty, “You are innocent,” will*ld be cursed by peoples and denounced by nations.
But*ln it will go well with those who convict the guilty, and*ld rich blessing will come on them.
An*pn honest answer is*ld like a kiss on the lips.
Put*pn your outdoor work in order and*ld get your fields ready; after*ld that, build your house.
Do*pn not testify against your neighbor without cause— would*ld you use your lips to mislead?
Do*ln not say, “I’ll do to them as they have done to me; I’ll*ld pay them back for what they did.”
I*pn went past the field of a sluggard, past*ld the vineyard of someone who has no sense;
thorns*ln had come up everywhere, the*ld ground was covered with weeds, and*ld the stone wall was in ruins.
I*ln applied my heart to what I observed and*ld learned a lesson from what I saw:
A*ln little sleep, a little slumber, a*ld little folding of the hands to rest—
and*ln poverty will come on you like a thief and*ld scarcity like an armed man.
